they're marked men they can't do those

nadir used to work with US Special
Forces yeah this is my home during a
raid he had an argument with his

sacked and added to the list he's taking
us to his family's village a year ago
the Taliban came here dragged him from
his home to the graveyard more men were
waiting for him there
they took my hand and brought me here
and their vehicle was parked here once I
saw the other two guys were inside their
vehicle they were armed with a rifle one

me if you're not going to go with as me
I'm going to shoot you in the face they
shot me here and it's a came out its
head here and came out from there the
only place which I was feeling myself it
was my own home but that home is became
a combat place for me the US State
Department told us we have the highest
respect for the men and women who take
enormous risks in supporting our
military
and civilian personnel the Secretary of
State has asked US Congress to provide

applicants so we can continue the
program in 2015 but those dismissed will
have a very hard time getting a visa
leaving these men without hope safety or
a future in their own country where they
are being pursued by the Taliban just
tell me why these translators are more
of a target than anyone else in Kabul I
thanks for having me first off they're
more of a target than anyone else
because of the simple fact that they've
been involved side by side with
coalition forces basically since the
beginning of the war my translator
Janice actually saved my life in a
firefight he literally shot and killed
two Taliban fighters who are about to to
kill me and I asked him about six months
later you know after I'd really got to
know him and serve with him why did he
ever cover up his face didn't he worry
about people recognizing him what
happens if if you know things went south
with the Taliban and they took back over
wouldn't he be worried about being
identified and what he told me is sort
of the sentiment that all these Afghans
had which is that is their country and
the Taliban are enemies to their people
and that they is Jana said the Taliban
ought to be afraid of me well every
translator is there for every raid every

think the Taliban is to remember
somebody like me or the Afghan that was
helping me out and translating for me
the person that ultimately they were
actually talking to but the United
States and the UK do have programs for
translators and we've just seen that in
our report tell us more about this
blacklist you know why some of these men
on a black list yeah so um there's
actually no really good program that
actually there's not like an official US
government program for the blacklist
it's sort of an amalgam of other various
programs that have become a nightmare
for these people what ends up happening
is is there is a list of people who are
sort of the known bad guys and the
terrorists and you want to have that
but too often the US military and NATO
allies have used this list who
essentially justify the firing of
translators there's almost no labor
rights law for example in Afghanistan
these people can be dismissed for just
about anything there's a company called
mission essential personnel that seems
to be behind the bulk of these of these
these people being added to this list
and a lot of the reasons that are cited
are absolutely not what not for you know
justified give an example I'm I have a
translator who I'm trying to help get
out of Afghanistan right now who was
fired because when he went home to
literally hand-deliver his paycheck so
that he could take care of him feed his
family he was fired because the Taliban
kidnapped him while he was at home not
allowing him to get back to his job and
the people on the job decided that he
had abandoned them at their most
vulnerable time and their most
vulnerable effort of a mission and just
said that's it this guy's gone and as a
result of that he got added to the
blacklist so there's there's no good
criteria there's also no way to appeal
one's being added to the list so it is
essentially a permanent punishment
without any trial any jury any judge to
appeal it - it needs to be stopped and
they're asked though a number of people
who have been settled in the United
States and your charity is helping them
yes I'm in the last five years the US

housing fully furnished their homes help
